learningContentbody.lcIntro:
Les topics DITA de type concept fournissent des informations sur un sujet particulier.
Les concepts aident quelqu'un à comprendre une idée ou le but d'une instruction. Un concept peut donner des informations générales ou conceptuelles sur le sujet en plus des informations essentielles.
Un topic typique de concept contiendra surtout des paragraphes et des listes. Cependant, vous pouvez utiliser des images, des tableaux et de nombreux autres éléments dans un concept. Vous pouvez également diviser un concept en sections pour plus de clarté.
Cette leçon montre comment créer un nouveau concept et comment ajouter des éléments couramment utilisés. A l'exception de l'élément <conbody>, les éléments présentés dans cette leçon et dans le reste du cours ne sont pas spécifiques aux concepts et peuvent également être utilisés dans les autres types de topics DITA (tâche et référence). x
Cette leçon couvre l'utilisation de base de ces éléments. Pour les spécifications complètes de chaque élément, se référer à Standard OASIS DITA Version 1.2.

lcInstruction.p: Téléchargez exemples_concept.zip maintenant. Il contient les fichiers d'exemple pour le cours entier de Rédaction de concepts DITA. Extrayez le contenu et placez le dans un répertoire auquel vous avez facilement accès.
À l'intérieur du dossier d'exemples, vous trouverez les dossiers suivants, correspondant aux leçons de ce cours: leçon1, leçon2, leçon3, et leçon4
Dans chaque dossier, vous trouverez quatre fichiers DITA :

li.p: l_nomfichier_debut.dita : Le fichier exemple vide auquel vous ajouterez du contenu au fur et à mesure que vous suivrez chaque leçon.
l_nomfichier.dita: La version complète du fichier exemple que vous pouvez utiliser pour vérifier votre travail.
l_nomfichier_exercice_debut.dita: Le fichier vide auquel vous ajouterez du contenu au fur et à mesure que vous complétez l'exercice à la fin de chaque leçon.
l_nomfichier_exercice.dita: La version complète du fichier d'exercice que vous pouvez utiliser pour vérifier votre travail..

lcInstruction.p: Chaque leçon vous indiquera quels fichiers utiliser pour les exercices. Sauvegardez votre fichier au fur et à mesure que vous complétez chaque étape pour éviter de perdre votre travail.

Créez une copie locale de chaque fichier au fur et à mesure que vous complétez les leçons. De cette façon, si vous arrivez à un point où votre fichier de travail ne correspond pas aux exemples, ou est cassé pour une raison quelconque, vous pouvez faire une nouvelle copie et reprendre votre travail ou recommencer.

Dans les instructions et les exemples, nous vous montrons le code DITA pour chaque fichier échantillon. La plupart des éditeurs DITA ont des fonctions d'auto-complétion ou d'autres fonctions similaires pour vous guider à travers le processus d'ajout d'éléments (par exemple, si vous tapez la balise d'ouverture d'une balise la plupart des éditeurs DITA ajouteront automatiquement la balise de fermeture pour vous). Par conséquent, vous n'aurez probablement pas besoin de créer tous les morceaux de code à partir de zéro lorsque vous travaillez. Nos vidéos de démonstration ont été réalisées avec oXygen XML Editor et montrent les différences entre le travail en vue auteur, qui présente le contenu de DITA dans une interface visuelle conviviale, et le travail en vue texte, qui affiche le code DITA.

Les topics concept contiennent des éléments de base de DITA, tels que des paragraphes, des listes, des images, des tableaux et bien d'autres. La plupart de ces éléments peuvent également être utilisés dans les autres types de topic (tâche et référence). La seule exception est l'élément <conbody>, qui est spécifique au type de topic concept.
Au minimum, le topic concept doit contenir un élément <concept> racine (avec un attribut id) qui contient un élément <title>.
Après l'élément <title> et un élément optionnel <shortdesc> ou <abstract>, l'élément <conbody> contient le concept lui-même.

L'élément <conbody> a un modèle de contenu ouvert. Cela signifie que les éléments contenus dans <conbody> ne sont pas tenus de suivre une séquence stricte. Tant qu'un élément est autorisé à l'intérieur, il peut apparaître dans n'importe quel ordre. Les exceptions sont les éléments <section> et <exemple>, qui ne peuvent être suivis que par d'autres éléments <section> ou <exemple> ou un élément <conbodydiv>.
Vidéo : Créer un concept DITA

step.cmd: Faites une copie du fichier leçon1/l_nouveau_concept_debut.dita et ouvrez-le dans votre éditeur.

note.p: Si vous utilisez un éditeur de texte compatible DITA, assurez-vous que vous êtes en mode texte plutôt qu'en mode auteur ou visuel.

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="mon_premier_concept"> <title>xyz</title> </concept>

info.p: La première ligne (qui commence par <?xml) est une déclaration XML, qui est une partie standard de tous les fichiers XML.
La déclaration DOCTYPE sur la deuxième ligne identifie ce fichier comme un topic de type concept.
La troisième ligne est la balise d'ouverture de l'élément <concept>, qui utilise l'identifiant unique "mon_premier_concept".
L'élément <title> sur la quatrième ligne contient le titre du topic.
La cinquième ligne utilise la balise de fermeture </concept> pour montrer où se termine l'élément <concept>.

step.cmd: A l'intérieur de l'élément <title>, modifiez le texte du titre comme indiqué dans l'exemple suivant.

note.p: Lorsque vous travaillez à l'intérieur d'un élément, insérez le contenu entre les balises d'ouverture et de fermeture.

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="mon_premier_concept"> <title>Espèces de canards sauvages</title> </concept>

step.cmd: Après l'élément <title>, ajoutez un élément <conbody>.

note.p: Lors de l'ajout d'un élément après un autre élément, insérer le nouvel élément après la balise de fermeture du premier élément.

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="mon_premier_concept"> <title>Espèces de canards sauvages</title> <conbody> </conbody> </concept>

step.info: L'élément <conbody> contiendra tout le contenu réel du concept.

Content strategy and business goals

The issues to consider are:

  • The real cost of low-cost documentation
  • How to create an efficient content development process

To implement your project and improve your chances of success, we recommend following this sequence:

  1. Identify and interview stakeholders.
  2. Establish implementation goals and metrics.
  3. Define roles and responsibilities.
  4. Establish timelines and milestones.
  5. Build the content creation system.
  6. Convert legacy content.
  7. Deliver content.
  8. Capture project knowledge.
  9. Ensure long-term success.

Ajouter les éléments <fig> et <image> au concept.
Reconnaître les éléments de base nécessaires pour ajouter des tableaux à un concept.
Ajouter les éléments <simpletable> et <table> à un concept.

lcIntro.p: Les images et les tableaux vous donnent un moyen visuel de présenter ou de clarifier l'information dans votre concept.
En utilisant l'élément <image> seul ou à l'intérieur d'un élément <fig>, vous pouvez inclure une image à votre concept via un lien vers l'emplacement de cette image sur le web ou un serveur local.

Avec les éléments <simpletable> et <table>, vous pouvez créer des tableaux pour transmettre des informations factuelles dans un format visuel clair. L'élément <simpletable> est idéal pour un petit tableau de base qui accompagne d'autres textes, tandis que l'élément <table> est idéal pour concevoir des tableaux complexes.

Cette leçon montre comment ajouter des images et des tableaux à un concept. Comme les autres éléments présentés dans ce cours, les images et les tableaux ne sont pas exclusifs au topic de type concept et peuvent également être utilisés dans les autres types de topic DITA (tâche et référence).

note.p: Cette leçon couvre l'utilisation de base de ces éléments. Pour les spécifications complètes de chaque élément, se référer à la Norme OASIS DITA Version 1.2.

learningContent.title: Ajouter des images à un concept

lcInstruction.p: Vous ajoutez des images à un concept en utilisant l'élément <image>. L'élément <image> utilise l'attribut href pour créer un lien vers l'emplacement de l'image sur le web ou sur un serveur local.

Tout comme un élément

, vous pouvez utiliser l'élément n'importe où dans l'élément . Il est aussi assez courant d'utiliser des images à l'intérieur d'un élément

.
Si votre image a besoin d'un titre ou d'une légende, utilisez l'élément <fig> (ou figure). L'élément <fig> peut contenir un élément <title> et un ou plusieurs éléments <image>.
Vidéo : Créer une figure avec une image dans DITA

step.cmd: Faites une copie du fichier leçon2/l_concept_images_tableaux_debut.dita et ouvrez-le dans votre éditeur.
step.info: Vous devriez avoir ceci :

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="concept_images_tables"> <title>Croissance et développement du caneton</title> <conbody> </conbody> </concept>

step.cmd: Insérer un élément <image> dans l'élément <conbody> comme indiqué dans l'exemple suivant. Utilisez le fichier leçon2/images/canetons_nageant.jpg comme image, par exemple :

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="concept_images_tables"> <title>Croissance et développement du caneton</title> <conbody> <image href="images/canetons_nageant.jpg"/> </conbody> </concept>

step.info: (Source de l'image d'exemple : Flickr, Micolo J)

L'élément <image> que vous avez ajouté contient un lien (href) vers l'emplacement du fichier image. Un lien à l'intérieur d'un élément <image> peut pointer vers le chemin du fichier image sur un serveur ou vers un lien web de l'image.

step.cmd: Après l'élément <image>, insérez un élément <fig> comme indiqué dans l'exemple suivant.Utilisez le fichier leçon2/images/canetons_courant.jpg comme image, par exemple :

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="concept_images_tables"> <title>Croissance et développement du caneton</title> <conbody> ... <fig> <title>Canetons courant</title> <image href="images/canetons_courant.jpg"/> </fig> </conbody> </concept>

step.info: (Source de l'image d'exemple : Flickr, Airwolfhound)
L'élément <fig> est une autre façon d'ajouter une image à un concept.
L'élément que vous avez ajouté contient un élément <title> et un élément <image>. L'élément <title> vous permet d'associer une légende à votre image.
L'élément <image> est structuré de la même manière à l'intérieur de l'élément <fig> qu'à l'intérieur de l'élément <conbody>.
L'élément <fig> peut contenir un ou plusieurs éléments <image> (mais un seul élément <title>).

note.p: Dans un élément <fig>, l'élément <title> précède toujours l'élément <image> dans DITA, mais la légende peut apparaître au-dessus ou au-dessous de l'image (ou ailleurs) dans la sortie finale.

learningContent.title: Ajouter des tableaux simples à un concept

lcInstruction.p: Il y a deux éléments disponibles pour créer des tables dans un concept : <simpletable> et <table>.

Utilisez l'élément <simpletable> chaque fois que vous le pouvez, en particulier pour les tableaux courts. Utilisez l'élément <table> pour les tableaux plus important ou les tableaux qui nécessitent un formatage plus complexe.
Les éléments contenus dans l'élément <simpletable> comprennent :

stentry.p: Élément conteneur pour la ligne d'en-tête d'un élément <simpletable>. L'élément <sthead> contient l'élément <stentry> et est facultatif. Il ne peut y avoir qu'un seul élément <sthead> dans un élément <simpletable>.
Élément conteneur pour les lignes du corps d'un élément <simpletable>. L'élément <strow> contient l'élément <stentry>. Un élément <simpletable> peut avoir un ou plusieurs éléments <strow>.

Élément conteneur pour une cellule unique dans un élément . L'élément contient le texte d'une cellule dans l'élément , qui devrait être encadré dans un élément

selon les meilleures pratiques.

learningContent.title: Adding tables to a concept topic

lcInstruction.p: Use the <table> element when you need to create a larger or more complex table than you can with the <simpletable> element. If you need a title or caption for your table, or more than one header row, use the <table> element.
The elements contained in the <table> element include:

strow.stentry: The container element for the text of a <table> element’s title or caption. A <table> element can only contain one <title> element.

The container element for the main content of a <table> element. The <tgroup> element contains the <colspec>, <thead>, and <tbody> elements. A <table> element can contain one or more <tgroup> elements.

The element that provides information about the columns in a <table> element. The column specifications are defined using the colname (the name of the column), colnum (the order in which the column appears), and colwidth (the relative width of the column) attributes.
The container element for the header in a <table> element. The <thead> element can contain one or more <row> elements and is optional.
The container element for the body rows in a <table> element. The <tbody> element can contain one or more <row> elements.
The container element for a row of cells in a <table> element. The <row> element contains one or more <entry> elements.

The container element for a single cell in a element. The element contains the text of a cell in the
element, which should be wrapped in a

element according to best practice.

lcInstruction.p: This lesson will cover the basics of using the <table> element. To highlight the differences between the <table> and <simpletable> elements, you will be using the same sample content for your <table> exercise as you used for your <simpletable> exercise.
Continue using the file lesson2/l_concept_images_tables_start.dita to add the <table> element.

note.p: If you are using a DITA editor, some child elements of the <table> element will automatically be inserted as you work through the examples.

note.p: This video shows an alternative way to create a table in DITA using the oXygen XML Editor table wizard. The exercises show you how to create a table using DITA code.

step.info: The <title> element is optional, but it allows you to add context to your table, just as it does for images when used inside the <fig> element.

step.cmd: After the <title> element, add the <tgroup> element as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="concept_images_tables"> <title>Duckling growth and development</title> <conbody> ... <title>Typical development of mallard ducks</title> <tgroup cols="2"> </tgroup> ... </conbody> </concept>

step.info: The <tgroup> element contains the body of the table. The number of table columns is set inside the <tgroup> element using the cols attribute. In the example you added, cols="2" shows that this table will contain two columns.
A single <table> element can contain more than one <tgroup> element, which is useful if you need to show more than one table with different headers or numbers of columns under the same title.

step.cmd: Inside the <tgroup> element, add two <colspec> elements and add content to them as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="concept_images_tables"> <title>Duckling growth and development</title> <conbody> ... <tgroup cols="2"> <colspec colname="c1" colnum="1" colwidth="1.0*"/> <colspec colname="c2" colnum="2" colwidth="1.0*"/> ... </conbody> </concept>

step.info: The <colspec> element sets up your table columns and specifies information about them (such as their names, sequence, and widths) using attributes. In the example you added, the colname attribute was used to name your columns "c1" and "c2" and the colnum attribute was used to designate the order in which these columns appear.

The optional colwidth attribute can be used to control the proportions of the column widths. In the example you added, the colwidth attribute is the same for each column, meaning that they will display at equal widths.

step.cmd: After the last <colspec> element, add the <thead> element as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="concept_images_tables"> <title>Duckling growth and development</title> <conbody> ... <colspec colname="c2" colnum="2" colwidth="1.0*"/> <thead> </thead> ... </conbody> </concept>

step.info: The <thead> element contains the elements associated with the table header. Unlike the <sthead> element in a <simpletable> element, the <thead> element in a <table> element can contain more than one header row.

lcObjectivesGroup.lcObjective: Learn about more elements and identify best practices for adding them to a concept topic.
Add the <b>, <i>, <u>, <term>, <cite>, <varname>, <sub>, <sup>, <dl>, <menucascade>, and <fn> elements to the concept.

lcIntro.p: You may need more specific elements in your concept topic than basic body elements, images, and tables. Maybe you need to indicate that certain words or phrases are important, or you need a more sophisticated way to define terms or provide references.

Some frequently used elements in DITA for inline styling include the <b>, <i>, <u>, <sub>, and <sup> elements. DITA also offers the <term>, <cite>, and <varname> elements as alternatives for inline styling that have more semantic value, or provide more information about the content.
Other useful elements include <fn> for inserting footnotes, <menucascade> for showing the order of software menu choices, and <dl> for creating lists of terms and their definitions.

This lesson introduces these elements and shows how to add them to a concept topic. Like the other elements introduced in this course, these elements are not exclusive to the concept topic type and can also be used in the other DITA topic types (task and reference).

note.p: This lesson covers basic use of these elements. For the full specifications for each element, see the OASIS DITA Version 1.2 Standard.

lcInstruction.p: DITA uses several elements for inline styling, or styling of pieces of text inside a paragraph:

stentry.p: a word or phrase that needs a definition
a word or phrase that needs a citation
a word or phrase that may change based on the user’s circumstances

lcInstruction.p: The inline elements <b>, <i>, and <u> are familiar and easy to use. However, because they are closely linked with the appearance of text, it is easy to misuse them and defeat the purpose of separating content from formatting. Use these elements sparingly; in most cases, it is better to use more meaningful elements instead, such as the <term>, <cite>, or <varname> elements.
In the following examples, you will learn how to insert the simple <b>, <i>, and <u> elements first, then how to replace them with the semantically rich alternatives.

step.cmd: Make a copy of the file lesson3/l_concept_elements_start.dita and open it in your editor.

note.p: If you are using a DITA-aware text editor, make sure you are in text mode, rather than author or visual mode.

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="concept_elements"> <title>Feeding ducklings</title> <conbody> </conbody> </concept>

element containing , , and elements as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre:
Feeding ducklings

Ducklings need round-the-clock access to both food and water during the first two weeks of their lives.

step.info: By adding the <b> element to this paragraph, you have indicated that the words “round-the-clock access” should be rendered in boldface. Similarly, by adding the <i> element, you have indicated that the words “food” and “water” should be rendered in italic, and by adding the <u> element, you have indicated that the words “two weeks” should be rendered with an underline.

Although these inline elements add emphasis to important words, they have no other semantic value. Suppose you wanted to define the words “round-the-clock access” later, or to style them the same way as other words describing feeding frequency. Rather than using the <b> element to tag the words simply as bold, you could use the <term> element to tag them as an important term.
There are similar, more semantically rich alternatives for the <i> and <u> elements, as you will see in the next step.

Ducklings need round-the-clock access to both food and water during the first two weeks of their lives.

step.info: In this example, you have tagged “round-the-clock access” with the <term> element to show that it is a term that should be defined later. You have tagged “food” and “water” with the <cite> element to show that they are words that could be given bibliographic citations should you need them. Finally, you have tagged “two weeks” with the <varname> element to show that it may need to be substituted with other information based on the user’s circumstances (for example, certain breeds of ducks may need round-the-clock access to food and water longer than two weeks).

step.info: The <sup> element is used to tag superscript text, or text that appears smaller and slightly above the main line. In the example you added, the <sup> element is used to indicate that the “2” (symbol for “squared”) in the name of the duck food company (“E-Z-Feed2”) should be displayed as superscript. Do not use <sup> elements to create raised numbers for footnotes. Instead, use the DITA <fn> (footnote) element, which we will cover later in this lesson.

lcInstruction.p: DITA uses many other important elements. Here are three more:

stentry.p: The element that inserts a footnote.

The element that indicates the order of a menu path, such as File > Save As. The <menucascade> element must contain one or more <uicontrol> elements. Each <uicontrol> element contains the text for a menu item.

The element that contains a definition list. A definition list is a list of terms and their corresponding definitions, presented in a format similar to a two-column table by default. The definition list contains one or more entries, tagged with the <dlentry> element, and each entry contains a term (tagged with the <dt> element) and one or more definitions (tagged with the <dd> element).

You can use the <uicontrol> element without the <menucascade> element. For example, you can tag a word with the <uicontrol> element to indicate a button the user should click. info.pre:
Increasing product visibility

Technical content can help organizations increase the visibility of their products in the marketplace. Officially, technical content is intended for product customers—people who buy a product and then look at the documentation.

But one opinion poll indicates that about one-third of buyers1 look at the documentation before buying a product, and the quality of the documentation will affect their purchasing decision.

To reel in new prospects, your content must perform in three different ways: be searchable, findable, and discoverable.

Searchable Information must be available via an internet search. Findable Information must perform well for relevant keywords. Discoverable Information must increase the likelihood that people will link to your information.

To read more, go to Contents > Business goals > Marketing and product visibility > Increasing product visibility.

1 "Consumer Feelings about Product Documentation,” an opinion poll conducted online by Sharon Burton

lcObjectivesGroup.lcObjective: Learn about advanced elements and identify best practices for adding them to a concept topic.
Add the <codeblock>, <codeph>, <lq>, <section>, <draft-comment>, and <required-cleanup> elements to the concept.

lcIntro.p: Now that you’ve mastered using the basic DITA elements and other commonly used ones, you’re ready to start using some more advanced elements in your concept topic.
You can use the <codeblock> and <codeph> elements to insert snippets of code into the body of your topic. With the <lq> element, you can insert a quote and create a link to its original source.

If you need to break your topic into subsections, you can add one or more <section> elements. The <section> element comes with two constraints: you can only use the <section> element inside of the <conbody> element, not inside of other <section> elements, and you can only follow a <section> element with another <section> element, an <example> element, or a <conbodydiv> element.

You can collaborate with other authors using the <draft-comment> element to make notes on pieces of information, or you can use the <required-cleanup> element to show that an element needs to be tagged correctly.

This lesson introduces these advanced elements and shows how to add them to a concept topic. Like the other elements introduced in this course, these elements are not exclusive to the concept topic type and can also be used in the other DITA topic types (task and reference).

note.p: This lesson covers basic use of these elements. For the full specifications for each element, see the OASIS DITA Version 1.2 Standard.

lcInstruction.p: Here are some common advanced elements in DITA:

stentry.p: The container element for a piece of code. Typically, it is rendered in a monospace font in PDF or HTML output. Placing content inside the <codeblock> element gives you control over line breaks.

The container element that displays a single word or phrase inside a

element as code. For example, if you mention an element in a paragraph and want to display only that element’s name in a monospace font, the element is useful.
The container element for including a quote from an outside source in your content rather than (or in addition to) linking to the source.

step.cmd: Make a copy of the file lesson4/l_concept_advanced_start.dita and open it in your editor.

note.p: If you are using a DITA-aware text editor, make sure you are in text mode, rather than author or visual mode.

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="concept_advanced"> <title>Writing about ducks</title> <conbody> </conbody> </concept>

step.info: Video: Creating a codeblock in DITA

step.cmd: Inside the <conbody> element, add the <codeblock> element and add content to it as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="concept_advanced"> <title>Writing about ducks</title> <conbody> <codeblock> duckdata> add entry (mallard) ; 1 entry added (0.05 sec) duckdata> _ </codeblock> </conbody> </concept>

step.info: The <codeblock> element isolates the piece of code content so that any tags in it exist for display purposes only and do not affect the DITA tags in your concept topic file.
The <codeblock> element also allows you to control line breaks. In the example you added, the text inside the <codeblock> element shows an entry being added to a database using the command line.

note.p: If you need an opening tag in a <codeblock> element, type < in place of the opening tag character (<). If you are working in the author or visual mode of a DITA editor, you can type the opening tag character inside a <codeblock> element, and the <codeblock> element will automatically render it as < in the text.

step.info: In the example you added, the <codeph> element allows you to isolate the words “add entry” and indicate that they should be displayed in a monospace font to show that they are a command.

step.info: In the example you added, the <lq> element allows you to include a quote from Walden by Henry David Thoreau.

The <lq> element can contain a link to the quote’s source. In the example you added, the <lq> element contains an href attribute pointing to the source URL, a format attribute indicating that the source is HTML, and a scope attribute showing that the source is external.

lcInstruction.p: Here are some more common advanced elements in DITA:

stentry.p: The element that divides the body of a topic into subsections with individual titles. The <section> element can contain a <title> element to give it a heading, along with most of the same elements allowed inside the <conbody> element. However, the <section> element cannot contain other <section> elements and can only be followed by another <section> element, an <example> element, or a <conbodydiv> element.

note.p: If you find that you are adding many sections or sections of substantial length to a topic, make each of those sections into its own topic instead so that you can reuse the information more easily.

stentry.p: The element that lets you insert comments and questions into the content while it is being developed. By default, the <draft-comment> element is hidden in the final output, so you can render output without deleting all draft comments. (You have to decide whether you’re willing to risk it, though!)
The element that lets you wrap content that is tagged incorrectly and needs to be fixed. By default, any content inside the <required-cleanup> element is hidden in output.

info.pre:
Developing a technical content strategy

After reviewing the existing information products, you should have a list of content challenges and ideas for improvement. Here are some common scenarios.

Reuse between technical documentation and training materials
The training department uses reference and task information created by the technical documentation team, but the instructional designers copy and paste instead of linking because the two groups use different, incompatible content creation tools. Comment: Add: "If the two teams standardized on a single workflow, they could share content seamlessly and avoid lots of tedious reworking."
HTML output is needed in addition to PDF

Your content may look like this in HTML:

<div class="p">You may produce high-value content, such as the following: <ul class="ul"> <li class="li"><p class="p">Training materials</p></li> <li class="li"><p class="p">White papers</p></li> <li class="li"><p class="p">Knowledge base articles</p></li> </ul> </div>

The <div> contains the unordered list.

Technical content is outdated because of inefficient updating process
The book production process—generating tables of contents and indexes, checking pagination, creating change page logs, and similar tasks—takes a significant amount of time. As a result, books are only updated twice a year. But the product is changing quarterly or even monthly, so the technical documentation is almost always out of date. Readers are complaining about the lack of synchronization between the product updates and the content updates.

learningContentbody.lcIntro: This lesson covers best practices for authoring concept topics. You will learn about the benefits of separating content from formatting, using DITA elements consistently, and creating semantically rich content.

link.linktext: DITA Style Guide, The separation of content and form
DITA Style Guide, Language and punctuation

lcInstruction.p: One of the major benefits of creating structured content in DITA is the separation of content from formatting. Content that is tagged according to its structure rather than its appearance will be more flexible in its output capabilities.

For example, an unstructured piece of content that has been created with page layout in mind will work best in print or PDF output, and may work poorly or not at all in an HTML-based output. However, a structured DITA topic with no formatting specified in the content should work equally well in multiple output types.

For authors who are accustomed to a formatting-based environment such as a desktop publishing program, it can be tempting to misuse the DITA tags to try to control the look and feel of the content. Using tags for a purpose other than they were intended decreases the value of those tags. Tag abuse can also have unintended consequences—a misused tag may achieve the desired formatting effect in one output type, but destroy the look and feel of the content in another output type.

One form of tag abuse is the forced line break. Do not use the

element to control where your lines of text should break, as this will cause problems in responsive output types such as HTML. Use the element to control line breaks for certain parts of your content (for example, code samples).
Because DITA content exists separately from formatting, consistent use of the DITA structure and tags is key to ensuring that all of your output types will look the way you expect.
One negative side effect of inconsistent tagging is mixed content. Suppose you have the following unordered list:

In this example, the last list item contains two paragraphs. Because the

element is valid inside the

  • element, it is possible to tag each paragraph separately. However, tagging this content as shown in the example means that you now have mixed content—the last
  • element has one line of text tagged simply with the
  • element, and another line with

    tags around it. This could affect the styling of the text of this list item in the final output.

To avoid having mixed content, surround all text inside an
  • element with

    tags, whether you are tagging one paragraph or more:

In addition to the
  • element, we recommend that text inside the , , and elements be surrounded with

    tags in case there are multiple paragraphs. To help ensure consistency and avoid mixed content, use the

    tag for any text that does not need to be tagged in a specific way.
One of DITA’s advantages is the ability to create semantically rich content, or content in which the element tags contain information about the content.

For example, using the <term> element may simply cause a word to display as bold text in the output, but the tag conveys much more information than just "render as boldface"—it shows that this word is a term that needs to be defined.

To take advantage of the semantically rich aspect of DITA, tag each piece of content with the element that most closely reflects what the content is and how it should be used. For example, use elements such as <term> or <cite> to highlight important words rather than simply using <b> or <i>.

Proper use of topic types also makes your content more semantically rich. For example, write step-by-step procedures in a task topic instead of a concept topic. That way, you can use the structure that DITA provides for creating steps, which provides much better information about the steps than using the <ol> element in a concept topic.
